CONARA Name: Surbiton Town Centre Conservation Area
AIRCZ Type:: Gatwick Airport Wind Turbine Consultation Zone:Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Gatwick Airport Limited, 7th Floor Destinations Place, London Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH06 0NP

AIRCZ Type:: Heathrow Planning Consultation Zone: All buildings, structures, erections and works exceeding 90 metres in height (295.3 feet)Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Heathrow Airport Limited, c/o Planning Services, First Point, Buckingham Gate, Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH6 0NT

description: Conversion of part building at rear to accommodate a self-contained two-bedroom duplex residential apartment.
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason:  As required  by Section 91 of  the Town  and Country Planning  Act  1990,  as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

The facing materials to be used in the construction of the proposed development hereby permitted shall be those specified on the application form and approved drawings or such other materials as have been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before the development is commenced and shall thereafter be retained as such. Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Cycle storage facilities shall be provided prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted in accordance with details which shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority, such facilities to be permanently retained at the site. Reason: To ensure the provision of cycle storage facilities to the satisfaction of the Council in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Refuse storage facilities and recycling facilities shall be provided prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted in accordance with details which shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to the commencement of the development, such facilities to be permanently retained at the site. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development shall either be stored within this dedicated store/area as shown on the approved plans, or internally within the building(s) that form part of the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material shall be stored or placed for collection on the public highway or pavement, except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure the provision of refuse facilities to the satisfaction of the Council in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Evidence must be submitted to the Council confirming that the development hereby permitted has achieved no less than the C02 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes Level 4.  Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of Evidence Required for Post Construction Stage from ENE1 and WAT1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Guide.  Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 Part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105L/day.Reason: In the interests of Sustainability and Energy Conservation in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (July 2011) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to occupation, obscure glazing shall be installed as shown on drawing No. 2B, the obscure glazing shall be non-openable below the level of 1.7m above adjacent floor level and shall be retained as such. Reason: In order to protect the amenity of the occupiers of neighbouring property from overlooking in accordance with Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to occupation of the development hereby approved the applicant shall provide a scheme to the Local Planning Authority for its written approval detailing sound transmission reduction measures to be installed:a) between the separating floor/ceiling and wall constructions of the new residential unit and the adjoining residential and commercial parts of the building.The scheme of noise insulation measures shall be prepared by a suitably qualified consultant/engineer and shall take into account the provisions of BS 8233: 2014 Guidance on sound insulation and noise reduction for buildings. The approved scheme shall be implemented prior to the commencement of the use and be permanently retained thereafter.Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of residential occupiers from the current and potential future use of the lower ground floor in accordance with Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.2 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. London Borough of Richmond - No objectionThe key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: While the proposed rear extension would measure 4m in depth which is over the parameters of the Residential Design SPD (4m v 3 - 3.5m depth), however given the modest height, would appear a proportionate addition to the host dwelling. Therefore, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The application site comprises an end terraced building located on the northern side of Kings Road. It is in mixed use with a vacant commercial unit at ground floor and residential above. The site is located within the Kings Road Local Centre and a 'Key Views' corridor. One objection has been received with respect of the single storey rear extension on the grounds that increasing the footprint of the site would result in a more intensive use; the rear extension would have an adverse impact on outlook; the proposal may be a precursor to a second storey extension; deliveries would now be taken from the rear; concerns in relation to use of the rear of the site as consulting rooms; and additional parking stress on Staunton Road.  Officer comment: The planning history confirms that a certificate of lawful development has been granted for the use of the ground floor for any use falling within Use Class E which permits the co-location of a number of uses. The application does not concern a change of use and is limited to operational development only. The proposed plans do indicate that the rear extension would enable the rear part of the commercial unit to be used as consulting rooms. Therefore, although the application does not concern a change of use it is clear that the applicant proposes to use the ground floor for at least two uses comprising a cafe and consulting rooms, both of which fall within uses Class E. It is recognised that the use of the application site could change to a number of uses falling within Class E without requiring planning permission, and it is not evident based on the information submitted with this application, that the proposed extension would lead to over intensive use of the site. Matters such as traffic/trip generation or parking requirements are not relevant to this application as it does not propose a change of use. Furthermore, in regards to the extension being a precursor to further extensions, all applications must be considered solely on their own merits. In regards to deliveries, the provision of the extension would not prevent deliveries being taken from the front if that was previously the case. As the proposal does not concern a change of use of the site, Officers are concerned that a condition pertaining to the deliveries would not meet the tests of the NPPF (2019). Comments in relation to impact on outlook are addressed below.The application as submitted included the provision of an extraction flue, however, following an objection from environmental health on the grounds of lack of information pertaining to noise and odour, the flue has been removed from the application. The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development, namely, the new shop front and rear extension is appropriate for a commercial premises. In regards to the immediate local context, it is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposal would not result in any adverse impacts for neighbouring occupiers as listed above. However, Officers are cognisant that permission exists for a the use of the upper floors for residential purposes and the use the roof on the rear extension as a roof terrace could have a detrimental impact on the amenities of residential occupiers so a condition is proposed to control this. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The applicant is advised that should protected species be found as a result of future development he/she must fulfil his/her duties under the Wildlife and Countryside Act, 1981 (as amended) and the Conservation of Habitats and Species Regulations, 2010.

Should there be a requirement to make alterations to vehicular access(s). Applicants should note the provisions of section 184 of the Highways Act 1980. The works should be to the specification and constructed to the satisfaction of the Council, and you will be required to pay fees to cover the Council's costs in undertaking the approval and inspection of the works.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.19 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: While the single storey side extension does not strictly accord with the parameters set by the Residential Design SPD, it would be set back from the front elevation, with a modest roof height and would be finished in materials in keeping with the host property. As such, the proposed development would appear as a subordinate addition to the original dwelling and would not appear out of keeping with the surrounding area.Therefore, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the separation distance between the proposed side extension and flank wall of No. 11 Lingfield Avenue, and that no side facing windows are proposed, the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of No. 11 Lingfield Avenue by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Further as the proposed side extension would not extend past the existing rear elevation of No. 17 Lingfield Avenue they would not be adversely affected by the proposed development by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.  In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Please revise existing ground floor plan at a recognised scale of 1:50 or 1:100, providing a scale bar, showing the outline of entire floor plan, not just part and all key dimensions for the proposed works.Note: Please provide existing ground floor plan without ancillary garden building, the submitted existing ground floor plan has foorprint of ancillary garden building.

Please provide existing and proposed roof plans at a recognised scale of 1:50 or 1:100, providing a scale bar, showing the outline of entire property not just part and showing dimensions of proposed work.

Please provide  proposed floor plans at a recognised scale of 1:50 or 1:100, providing a scale bar, showing the outline of entire floor plan, not just part and all key dimensions for the proposed works.Note: We received two different designs of proposed floor plans  04.A RevB Proposed Floor Plans, 04.B RevB Proposed Floor Plans, we require only one design of porposed floor plans.

Please provide proposed roof plans at a recognised scale of 1:50 or 1:100, providing a scale bar, showing the outline of entire property not just part and showing dimensions of proposed work.Note: We received two different designs of proposed roof plans, we require only one design of proposed roof plan.

You are required to complete the 'Determining whether a Development may be CIL Liable Planning Application Additional Information Requirement form'. This form can be downloaded from the planning portal at ecab.planningportal.co.uk/uploads/1app/forms/form_1_cil_additional_information.pdf . Please complete and return as soon as possible.If you have confirmed that the development is Cil Liable, please also complete the Assumption of Liability Form at www.planningportal.co.uk/info/200136/policy_and_legislation/70/community_infrastructure_levy/5  and return as soon as possible.

Please submit a revised copy of an Ordnance Survey based site location plan scaled 1:1250 with the application site outlined in red and adjoining land owned by applicant in blue, showing at least two road frontages and a North point.Please note that the complete site to be outlined in red (not just the building). This should also show 2 road frontages. Validation requirement 1d

As the proposed development is within flood zones 2 and 3 or on a site of more than 1ha, you are required to complete a Flood Risk form before the application can be assessed.  For further information and guidance on any aspects of undertaking a Flood Risk Assessment please contact the Environment Agency by visiting their website at http://planningguidance.communities.gov.uk/blog/guidance/flood-risk-and-coastal-change/site-specific-flood-risk-assessment-checklist/
